meta.title: Bad News: How Woke Media Is Undermining Democracy
meta.author: Batya Ungar-Sargon

parts.title: Introduction of "Bad News" Summary
parts.body: In 2018, CNN's Don Lemon hosted a panel about white women voting for Trump. Kirsten Powers called such women racist for supporting Trump over Hillary Clinton. Stephanie Jones-Rogers linked this to a historical context, and Alice Stewart opposed the racism label. This discussion reflects a moral panic on race that has spread from academics to the mainstream media, painting the US as systemically racist. While once a blue-collar field, journalism has shifted towards an elite status, focusing more on identity over economic inequality. This shift highlights the media's role in obscuring class inequalities using racial discourse, aligning with the interests of the affluent liberal elite.

parts.title: Abandonment of Working Class by Media
parts.body: The media powerhouse New York Times was central to formulating a tone that was seen as disastrous in the industry. This tone contributed to how liberal media disregarded the working class, while conservative outlets catered to them, albeit with their own biases. The economic struggles and cultural concerns of the working class, who value family and faith over resumes, were overlooked. A journalism that addresses this class divide, rather than hiding it, is crucial for a functioning democracy. Instead, today's press often sides with powerful elites rather than holding them accountable, worsening inequality and undermining democracy.

parts.title: The Respectability and Elite Readership of the New York Times
parts.body: Henry Raymond, founder of the New York Times, was known for his bourgeois politics of respectability. He made the paper serious, conservative, and focused on legal, commercial, and financial transactions, aiming at the middle and upper classes. The Times gained many readers from respectable families and emphasized civility and dignity, despite Raymond personally opposing laws like the Fugitive Slave Act and keeping his editorial page weak to maintain neutrality. This reflected a preference for conservative societal views and respectability over broader populist appeal, paving the way for a specific upper-middle-class readership. Adolph Ochs bought the Times in 1896 and maintained its respectability while appealing to the social elite, though being Jewish posed a social barrier. He focused the paper’s content on business and international news, avoiding scandal and tailoring it to affluent New Yorkers. Under Ochs’s guidance, the Times thrived, targeting those with expensive tastes, unlike Joseph Pulitzer's readers. This model of cultivating elite readership became profitable, attracting similar ventures, such as the New Yorker. The magazine catered to the wealthy urbanites, making clear that it wasn’t for the working class, thus securing profitable high-end advertising. This elitism in content and audience prevailed, reinforcing the economic divide within journalism.

parts.title: Journalism's Class Shift & Media Polarization
parts.body: A survey in 2018 revealed that around 65% of news interns at top outlets like Wall Street Journal, New York Times, and others, came from highly selective schools. This pattern holds for many high-profile journalists too, forming an exclusive network. These media organizations once included local and accessible reporting but have shifted to cater predominantly to higher-class and educated audiences. This has led to a disconnect from the general American public and an increased focus on an elite perspective. By the 1970s, news began targeting more specific, affluent audiences rather than the working class. This decline in class-based reporting was part of a broader industry shift towards market-driven news, influenced heavily by advertising demands. Subsequently, significant parts of the working class felt underrepresented, which media like conservative outlets then effectively addressed, filling the void left by mainstream media abandoning these communities. This shift exacerbated class divides in media consumption, aligning audience preferences along education and class lines as much as political ones.

parts.title: Far-Right Media's Often Misguided Focus on Racism
parts.body: Far-right media like Breitbart caters to the Alt-Right, linking people of color with crime. Fox News has fired staff for overt racism, yet much outrage over its racism claims are often about questioning liberal policies or criticizing figures of color. Criticism of Fox's racism sometimes overlooks its perspective that no race should receive "special favors" from the government. This reflects a Republican view and isn't exclusive to racial animosity. Many Critiques of Fox suggest a class bias, ignoring legitimate issues it highlights about class inequality.

parts.title: Shift in Media Narrative
parts.body: In today's media landscape, race and gender dominate discussions, overshadowing class issues. This shift coincided with Obama's presidency and the rise of digital news, as seen in data analyzed by David Rozado and Zach Goldberg. They pointed out a significant increase in words like "racism" and "white supremacy" across major outlets like the New York Times, starting around 2011. This change is attributed to the younger generation of journalists replacing traditional ones, bringing a more judgmental and ideological perspective to reporting. At the Times, this shift was encouraged as part of a digital strategy that valued social media presence and new digital talent over traditional reportage practices.

parts.title: Rise of Critical Race Theory and White Liberal Wokeness
parts.body: Critical race theory and wokeness have become prominent in the mainstream, shaping media and societal discussions on race. Authors like Ibram X. Kendi and Robin DiAngelo have popularized ideas that racism is not just about personal prejudice but is systemic, influencing corporate training and education. The media has embraced this framework, creating a culture where race is often the focal point. Despite claims of progress in racial equality, liberal whites have exhibited greater support for diversity and awareness of racial discrimination than people of color themselves. This divergence is highlighted in studies showing white liberals perceive more racism in society, even amid declining direct experiences of racism by minority groups. This phenomenon is driven in part by the media and critical race theory's focus on structural racism, leading to a "Great Awokening" among white liberals.

parts.title: Bari Weiss and the Struggles at the New York Times
parts.body: Bari Weiss’ time at the New York Times saw escalating tensions as identity politics became dominant. Weiss's attempts to publish diverse voices met resistance, and her stance on controversial topics led to bullying from colleagues. An infamous incident was the Tom Cotton op-ed, sparking outrage at the Times, demonstrating the media's role in moral panic. This resulted in a mass collective departure of staff from the Times who disagreed with representing the controversial viewpoints. The moral panic around race and identity was intensifying, influencing journalism and public discourse, with serious implications for the ability to hold a balanced debate in media outlets.

parts.title: Complex Racial Narratives and Individualism
parts.body: The chapter explores the influence of wokeness in media, highlighting how issues of race and power shape coverage. The 'What Killed Michael Brown?' film experienced pushback from Amazon, but was eventually released, illustrating power struggles over racial narratives. Kmele Foster's views are presented, as he identifies as "racially agnostic," rejecting the concept of race as a persistent hindrance, stressing individualism over racial identity. Foster's stance on racism highlights potential misinterpretations of interactions as racial when they may not be, thus losing humanity. His insights align with James Baldwin's fears of paranoia in hostility. Foster criticizes 'white privilege' narratives as presumptuous and sees racial slogans as disempowering, implying superiority and victimhood are misleading. This chapter illustrates complex debates around race in media and personal identity.

parts.title: The Role of Clerisy in Supporting the Oligarchy
parts.body: Today’s media and cultural elite function as a "clerisy," supporting the tech oligarchy by aligning with its values, such as globalism and environmentalism. This elite uses science and other doctrines to maintain a class hierarchy, pushing for "oligarchical socialism" and benefiting from redistribution, where the working class remains dependent on the super-rich. Both political parties fail to offer real alternatives, focusing instead on policies that maintain elite power, alienating the working class who desire more autonomy and community values, rather than expansion of the welfare state.

parts.title: Exploring Moral Panic and Debates in Journalism
parts.body:
Summary of Chapters 8-9: A Moral Panic and a Rich Debate within the Black Community

The moral panic surrounding racism has led to censorious journalism and media engagement. This panic stirs around incidents like those involving George Floyd, where the media's role instigates an intense response, leading to discussions on cancel culture. The intersectionality between race and journalism plays a part as media organizations, Hollywood, and public figures react swiftly to race-related issues, often leading to public outrage or resignations. Key figures like Tom Cotton and New York Times personnel highlight the tension between publishing controversial ideas and adhering to a socially sensitive ethos. This environment causes a social media outrage, every time someone voices contrarian opinions, igniting a possible moral panic. In the Black community, a rich debate occurs as these moral panics unfold. Discussions within the Black press highlight inequality, objectivity, and journalistic challenges. As some believe objectivity favors white journalists, others emphasize cultural overreach in media and cancel culture’s effects. Figures like Wesley Lowery critique the dominant rhetoric, urging a more nuanced conversation about race and journalism. The idea of the Black press as a means to challenge persistent stereotypes and issues is debated, indicating a need for diverse narratives within journalism to properly address racism and inform public discourse.
